page.title: 03THE ARMY IN WARMINSTER
page.content: Much of the town's prosperity depends directly or indirectly on the Army. The War Department was buying land on Salisbury Plain for training before 1914 but the main military presence came in 1937 when the School of Infantry moved here from Hythe. The School is now a major NATO training base. Battlesbury Barracks was built for troops who take part in exercises on the Plain, at present the 1st Battalion of the Worcestershire and Sherwood Foresters Regiment (known as the "Woofers"). Fighting vehicle workshops were added in 1939, now 27 District REME. Since the 1939-45 War the Ranges north and east of the town have been closed to the public, turning the village of Imber in the middle of the Plain into a "ghost town" only visited by soldiers, or locals on the few open days.
